trial_identification.studytitle: Pilot study evaluating the efficacy of MitoQ in adults with type II diabetes and coronary vascular disease.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A pilot study into the effects of MitoQ on endothelial function in participants with type II diabetes and coronary vascular disease.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Diseases of the vasculature and circulation including the lymphatic system

interventions.interventions: The study treatment will consist of 20mg oral MitoQ (Mitoquinol Mesylate) capsules taken orally once per day (4 x 5mg capsules) or matching placebo (4 x capsules). The active ingredient is MitoQ (Mitoquinol Mesylate). The adherence to treatment will be monitored via capsule count on return at 1 month. The treatment period is for 1 month.
interventions.comparator: matching placebo capsules containing: Chromium Picolinate, Zinc Amino Acid Chelate, Zinc, Cinnamomum Cassia.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The outcome measure is endothelial dilatation of the brachial artery using ultrasound to measure dilatation of the artery after 5 minutes of artery occlusion via a blood pressure cuff.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Change in serum marker from baseline to 1 month: C-Reactive Protein,
Change in serum vascular cell adhesion molecule (VCAM),
Change in serum Intercellular adhesion molecule (ICAM),
Change in serum tumour necrosis factor-a (TNF a).
Change in serum soluble P selectin.
Change in serum growth differentiation factor 15 (GDF 15).
Change in resting heart rate as assessed by automated blood pressure machine.
Incidence of adverse events will be recorded and reported during the study period. Known or expected side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and sleep disturbances.
Treatment interruption will be assessed via a pill count conducted at the end of the treatment period (1 month visit).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Participants are male or female aged >45 years and <70 years with a confirmed diagnosis of type II diabetes and coronary vascular disease currently taking at least one oral anti-hyperglycaemic medication.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Participants with a BMI>40 kg/m2, participants currently smoking, participants currently taking insulin, participants with use of open label Coenzyme Q10 Supplementation, participants who are currently taking Warfarin participants using antioxidants, participants with uncontrolled hypertension (>160/90 mmHg), participants allergic to any of the formulation excipients or mitoquinone mesylate will be excluded and participants unable to complete all study visits will also be excluded.

trial_design.concealment: treatment allocation is concealled by the method of numbered containers which have been randomly allocated to a treatment group by an independent statistician.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by computer software package.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: 1. The mean percentage change from baseline in FMD +/-standard error of the mean 2. Mean percentage change from baseline in heart rate compared to placebo. 3. Mean percentage change from baseline in HbA1c compared to placebo. 4. Mean percentage change e from baseline in biomarkers compared to placebo. 5. Number of subject withdrawals due to adverse effects compared to placebo.

fundingsource.fundingname: The funding is being provided Callaghan Innovation
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Quay Street Level 4 , 139 Quay Street Auckland 1010

fundingsource.fundingname: Funding is being provided by Antipodean Pharmaceuticals
fundingsource.fundingaddress: MitoQ Head Office: Level 2, 16 Viaduct Harbour Avenue, Auckland, 1010, New Zealand.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary aim of this project is to investigate the feasibility of the proposed study design. The study is designed to investigate the potential effects of MitoQ on the endothelial vascular system. A technique that is commonly used in research will be employed in this study. The technique is called Flow Mediated Dilatation (FMD). The primary objective for the project will be measured using the FMD technique. Secondary objectives include: looking at the effect on heart rate, blood sugar levels via the HbA1c test, checking the levels of certain biomarkers of inflammation and comparing the number of treatment interruptions in both arms of the study.
